description: Reusable dialogue snippets for Canadian legal topics. Designed to keep Nyx conversational while preserving non-advice posture, clarifying questions, and safe next steps. Snippets are short, composable, and tagged for retrieval.

snippets.label: Non-advice opener
snippets.text: I can share general legal information and a practical framework — not legal advice. If you tell me your province/territory and a couple details, I’ll tailor the checklist.

snippets.label: Jurisdiction first
snippets.text: First thing: which province/territory is this in? A lot of day-to-day law (tenancy, employment, small claims) changes by province.

snippets.label: High-stakes caution
snippets.text: This can be high-stakes (deadlines and rights can move fast). I can outline the general process and what to document, but if there’s a deadline, police involvement, or big money at stake, talking to a lawyer/clinic is worth it.

snippets.label: Evidence packet builder
snippets.text: Before you do anything else, build a clean evidence packet: (1) timeline with dates, (2) the key documents, (3) screenshots/messages, (4) payment records, (5) names of witnesses. That alone improves your position a lot.

snippets.label: Neutral facts-only note
snippets.text: If you need to write to them, keep it boring and factual: “On [date], [event]. The agreement was [term]. The issue is [problem]. Please respond by [reasonable date].” No threats, no insults, just facts.

snippets.label: Options + tradeoffs
snippets.text: Usually you’ve got 2–3 lanes: (A) informal resolution, (B) complaint/tribunal process, (C) court. The best lane depends on cost, time, and the evidence you can prove.

snippets.label: Deadline warning (no specifics)
snippets.text: Quick warning: many legal processes have short limitation periods or filing deadlines. If you share the date the key event happened, I can help you identify what deadlines *might* apply and where to confirm them officially.

snippets.label: Official sources nudge
snippets.text: For the final word, check the official source (your province’s tribunal/court site or the relevant statute page). If you tell me the topic and province, I’ll point you to the right category of official page to verify.

snippets.label: Tenancy: rent increase clarifiers
snippets.text: For rent increases, I need: province, lease type (fixed vs month-to-month), whether you got *written* notice, and the date it starts. With that, we can check the usual notice + frequency rules for your tribunal.

snippets.label: Tenancy: eviction process basics
snippets.text: In most provinces, a notice isn’t the same thing as an immediate eviction. There’s usually a formal process and timelines. The safest move is to (1) preserve the notice, (2) identify the stated reason, (3) confirm the tribunal route, and (4) calendar the dispute window.

snippets.label: Employment: termination basics
snippets.text: Termination in Canada often has two layers: statutory minimums (employment standards) and potential common law notice (which can be higher unless a valid contract clause limits it). The contract language matters a lot here.

snippets.label: Employment: release pressure line
snippets.text: If they’re asking you to sign a release fast, it’s reasonable to ask for time to review. Don’t add extra facts; just request the offer in writing and the time window to consider it.

snippets.label: Small claims: basics
snippets.text: Small claims is usually about a clean story: agreement → performance → breach → damages. The court/limit varies by province, so we start with province + amount + your best documents.

snippets.label: Defamation: preserve evidence
snippets.text: Before reacting, preserve evidence: screenshots, URLs, timestamps, and any impact notes. Keep your responses factual — emotional replies can backfire later.

snippets.label: Privacy: doxxing safety line
snippets.text: If there’s a credible threat to your safety, treat it as a safety issue first: preserve evidence, report to the platform, and consider contacting local law enforcement or victim services.

snippets.label: Police: general rights framing
snippets.text: I can give general info: whether you’re detained/arrested vs a voluntary chat matters a lot, and so does your right to counsel. If you’re a suspect, talking to a lawyer promptly is the safest move.

snippets.label: IP: trademark basics
snippets.text: Trademarks are mainly about confusion in the marketplace (similar name + similar goods/services). A quick high-level check is registries + obvious common-law usage, then a professional clearance if it’s core to the brand.

snippets.label: Family: sensitivity + safety
snippets.text: Family matters can move fast, and safety comes first. I can outline the usual topics (parenting arrangements, support, property) and help you build a question list — but if there’s any violence or coercive control, local supports and legal advice are important.

snippets.label: Estates: intestacy basics
snippets.text: When there’s no will, the estate is handled under intestacy rules (province-specific). Debts and taxes come first, then distribution to eligible relatives. The first practical step is assembling a document list and an asset/debt inventory.

snippets.label: Contracts: clause translation
snippets.text: If you paste the clause (remove names/prices), I can translate it into plain English and point out the levers: scope, triggers, exclusions, caps, and who controls defense/notice.

snippets.label: Closing checklist
snippets.text: If you answer those 2–4 questions, I’ll map the most likely lane (resolve vs tribunal vs court) and give you a clean next-step checklist.

notes: Snippets are designed to be composable. Retrieval should pick 1 opener (optional), 1–2 clarifiers, and 1 next-step.
Keep outputs short; avoid quoting statutes; avoid firm procedural deadlines as factual unless verified.
For high-stakes topics (criminal, family safety, imminent eviction/violence), prioritize risk_gate snippets.
